channel.title: Compile Error

item.title: Compile Error
item.dc:creator: @Demise Demise
item.description:
@Demise wrote:

[quote=“x blitz x, post:18, topic:250699”]Why not just have,

c.Send("X=" + absX + " Y=" + absY);

There is no need for the +"" at the end, this does nothing.

And for your final errors, you haven’t got absX and absY declared.[/quote]

OK then, and how do I declare them?

Read full topic

item.title: Compile Error
item.dc:creator: @x_blitz_x x blitz x
item.description:
@x_blitz_x wrote:

Well, it’s not finding the variables “absX” and “absY” inside the place he is trying to use them. So they’re not declared or he’s typed them wrong.

Read full topic

item.title: Compile Error
item.dc:creator: @x_blitz_x x blitz x
item.description:
@x_blitz_x wrote:

Why not just have,

c.Send("X=" + absX + " Y=" + absY);

There is no need for the +"" at the end, this does nothing.

And for your final errors, you haven’t got absX and absY declared.

item.title: Compile Error
item.dc:creator: @Demise Demise
item.description:
@Demise wrote:

.\Command.java:53: cannot find symbol symbol : variable absX location: class Command c.Send("X=" + absX + " Y=" + absY + ""); ^ .\Command.java:53: cannot find symbol symbol : variable absY location: class Command c.Send("X=" + absX + " Y=" + absY + ""); ^ Note: .\Stream.java uses or overrides a deprecated API. Note: Recompile with -Xlint:deprecation for details. 2 errors Press any key to continue . . .

That’s what I get when I use your thing.

Read full topic

item.title: Compile Error
item.dc:creator: @xxxxxx_13 xxxxxx 13
item.description:
@xxxxxx_13 wrote:

i agree with that. and the literal string has to be referring to the " so the last one is just matching up } the reason i dont like that source you are using is because sometimes the only way for it to compile right is if you dont have an even amount of open and closing…brackets for lack of the proper term. im no guru just a junkie.

edit lawl @ u for not following directions. you deleted the " before the x= i never said a thing about that. honestly i think you need the line to look like

		c.Send("X=" + absX + " Y=" + absY + "");

Or something like that. is what i would do.

Read full topic

item.title: Compile Error
item.dc:creator: @Demise Demise
item.description:
@Demise wrote:

.\Command.java:53: ')' expected c.Send(X=" + absX + " Y=" + absY +"); ^ .\Command.java:53: illegal start of expression c.Send(X=" + absX + " Y=" + absY +"); ^ .\Command.java:53: ';' expected c.Send(X=" + absX + " Y=" + absY +"); ^ .\Command.java:53: illegal start of expression c.Send(X=" + absX + " Y=" + absY +"); ^ 4 errors Press any key to continue . . .

That’s what I am getting now.
It’s easier now because it’s all on the same line!

Read full topic

item.title: Compile Error
item.dc:creator: @RSCReborn RSCReborn
item.description:
@RSCReborn wrote:

[quote=“xxxxxx 13, post:12, topic:250699”]ok the idea i gave you for adding a } didnt work it just added an error so lets not do that. umm… hmm oh no wait it didnt add an error it just didnt do anything. hmm… ihad a friend have a similar problem with probably the same source earlier today.

oh hah im slow mo. ok for the first errors. if you notice you have an odd number of " which you cant have. See if deleting that last one does anything. or better yet try adding a second " right beside it to the right. i mean im not sure. either could work.[/quote]

Just need to see more of the problem, looks like a tab/space issue on the second one

Read full topic

item.title: Compile Error
item.dc:creator: @Demise Demise
item.description:
@Demise wrote:

.\Command.java:52: unclosed string literal c.Send("X=" + absX + " Y=" + absY + "); ^ .\Command.java:52: ';' expected c.Send("X=" + absX + " Y=" + absY + "); ^ .\Command.java:238: reached end of file while parsing }→ ^ 3 errors Press any key to continue . . .

Here’s what I’ve got inside.

if (cmd.startsWith("server")) { c.Yell("[Server]: "+cmd.substring(7)+""); } if(cmd.startsWith("mypos")) { c.Send("X=" + absX + " Y=" + absY + "); } if (cmd.startsWith("emote")) { try { c.anim(Integer.parseInt(cmd.substring(6))); c.updateRequired = true; c.appearanceUpdateRequired = true; } catch (Exception e) { c.Send("Wrong Syntax! Use as ::emote #"); }

Halp?

Read full topic
